typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.coref.type.CoreferenceChain
typeDescription.description: Marks the beginning of a chain.

featureDescription.name: first
featureDescription.description: This is the first corefernce link in coreference chain

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.coref.type.CoreferenceLink
typeDescription.description: A link in the coreference chain.

featureDescription.name: next
featureDescription.description: If there is one, it is the next coreference link to the current coreference link

featureDescription.name: referenceType
featureDescription.description: The role or type which the covered text has in the coreference chain.

featureDescription.name: referenceRelation
featureDescription.description: The type of relation between this link and the next link in the chain.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.morph.MorphologicalFeatures
typeDescription.description: Morphological categories that can be attached to tokens.

featureDescription.name: number
featureDescription.description: Singular/plural

featureDescription.name: case
featureDescription.description: Nouns: nominative, genetiv, dative, ...

featureDescription.name: degree
featureDescription.description: Adjectives: comparative/Superlative

featureDescription.name: tense
featureDescription.description: Verbs: past tense, present tense, future tense, etc.

featureDescription.name: mood
featureDescription.description: Verbs: indicative, imperative, subjunctive

featureDescription.name: voice
featureDescription.description: Verbs: active/passive

featureDescription.name: definiteness
featureDescription.description: Definite or indefinite

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: The original morphological analysis results as produced by a tool or as recorded in a corpus (if available). If the categories were originally encoded in such a string, the other features are filled by analyzing this string. If the categories were provided separately, e.g. by different attributed in an XML-encoded corpus, this field may remain empty.

featureDescription.name: person
featureDescription.description: Verbs: 1st, 2nd, 3rd person

featureDescription.name: aspect
featureDescription.description: Verbs: perfective, imperfective

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.pos.O
typeDescription.description: Catch-all for other categories such as abbreviations or foreign words

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.pos.POS
typeDescription.description: The part of speech of a word or a phrase.

featureDescription.name: PosValue
featureDescription.description: The string representation of POS. Mostly it is the POS representation of the wrapped POS tagger.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.pos.tweet.AT
typeDescription.description: at-mention (indicates another user as a recipient of a tweet)

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.pos.tweet.DM
typeDescription.description: discourse marker, indications of continuation of a message across multiple tweets

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.metadata.type.DocumentMetaData
typeDescription.description:
The DocumentMetaData annotation stores information about a single processed document. There can only be one of these annotations per CAS. The annotation is created by readers and contains information to uniquely identify the document from which a CAS was created. Writer components use this information when determining under which filename a CAS is stored.

There are two principle ways of identifying a document:

  • collection id / document id: this simple system identifies a document within a collection. The ID of the collection and the document are each simple strings without any further semantics such as e.g. a hierarchy. For this reason, this identification scheme is not well suited to preserve information about directory structures.
  • document base URI / document URI: this system identifies a document using a URI. The base URI is used to derive the relative path of the document with respect to the base location from where it has been read. E.g. if the base URI is file:/texts and the document URI is file:/texts/english/text1.txt, then the relative path of the document is english/text1.txt. This information is used by writers to recreate the directory structure found under the base location in the target location.

It is possible and indeed common for a writer to initialize both systems of identification. If both systems are present, most writers default to using the URI-based systems. However, most writers also allow forcing the use of the ID-based systems.

In addition to the features given here, there is a language feature inherited from UIMA's DocumentAnnotation. DKPro Core components expect a two letter ISO 639-1 language code there.

featureDescription.name: documentTitle
featureDescription.description: The human readable title of the document.

featureDescription.name: documentId
featureDescription.description: The id of the document.

featureDescription.name: documentUri
featureDescription.description: The URI of the document.

featureDescription.name: collectionId
featureDescription.description: The ID of the whole document collection.

featureDescription.name: documentBaseUri
featureDescription.description: Base URI of the document.

featureDescription.name: isLastSegment
featureDescription.description: CAS de-multipliers need to know whether a CAS is the last multiplied segment. Thus CAS multipliers should set this field to true for the last CAS they produce.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.metadata.type.MetaDataStringField
typeDescription.description: A general purpose annotation to store document-wide information in the form of arbitrary key-value string pairs.

featureDescription.name: key
featureDescription.description: Name of a metadata field.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: The field value.

featureDescription.name: name
featureDescription.description: The name of the tag.

featureDescription.name: layer
featureDescription.description: The layer to which the tagset applies. This is typically the name of an UIMA type such as "de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.lexmorph.type.pos.POS".

featureDescription.name: name
featureDescription.description: The name of the tagset.

featureDescription.name: tags
featureDescription.description: Descriptions of the tags belonging to this tagset.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.ner.type.NamedEntity
typeDescription.description: Named entities refer e.g. to persons, locations, organizations and so on. They often consist of multiple tokens.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.Compound
typeDescription.description: This type represents a decompounding word, i.e.: flowerpot. Each Compound one have at least two Splits.

featureDescription.name: splits
featureDescription.description: A word that can be decomposed into different parts.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.CompoundPart
typeDescription.description: A CompoundPart represents one fragment from the compounding word. Besides that, it can store other CompoundParts if it can be split again. The way it stores a decompounding word represents a decompounding tree.

featureDescription.name: id
featureDescription.description: If this unit had an ID in the source format from which it was imported, it may be stored here. IDs are typically not assigned by DKPro Core components. If an ID is present, it should be respected by writers.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.LinkingMorpheme
typeDescription.description: This type represents a linking morpheme between two CompoundParts.

featureDescription.name: id
featureDescription.description: If this unit had an ID in the source format from which it was imported, it may be stored here. IDs are typically not assigned by DKPro Core components. If an ID is present, it should be respected by writers.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.Split
typeDescription.description: This type represents a part of a decompounding word. A Split can be either a CompoundPart or a LinkingMorpheme.

featureDescription.name: splits
featureDescription.description: Sub-splits of the current split.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.segmentation.type.Token
typeDescription.description: Token is one of the two types commonly produced by a segmenter (the other being Sentence). A Token usually represents a word, although it may be used to represent multiple tightly connected words (e.g. "New York") or parts of a word (e.g. the possessive "'s"). One may choose to split compound words into multiple tokens, e.g. ("CamelCase" -> "Camel", "Case"; "Zauberstab" -> "Zauber", "stab"). Most processing components operate on Tokens, usually within the limits of the surrounding Sentence. E.g. a part-of-speech tagger analyses each Token in a Sentence and assigns a part-of-speech to each Token.

featureDescription.name: parent
featureDescription.description: the parent of this token. This feature is meant to be used in when the token participates in a constituency parse and then refers to a constituent containing this token. The type of this feature is {@link Annotation} to avoid adding a dependency on the syntax API module.

featureDescription.name: morph
featureDescription.description: The morphological feature associated with this token.

featureDescription.name: id
featureDescription.description: If this unit had an ID in the source format from which it was imported, it may be stored here. IDs are typically not assigned by DKPro Core components. If an ID is present, it should be respected by writers.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.semantics.type.SemanticArgument
typeDescription.description: The SemanticArgument annotation is attached to semantic arguments of semantic predicates. Semantic arguments are characterized by their semantic role, e.g. Agent, Experiencer, Topic. The semantic role of an argument is related to its semantic type (for communication verbs, the Agent can be a person or an organization, but typically not food). The semantic type of arguments is not yet covered by the SemanticType.

featureDescription.name: role
featureDescription.description: The role which the argument takes. The value depends on the theory being used, e.g. Arg0, Arg1, etc. or Buyer, Seller, etc.

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.semantics.type.SemanticField
typeDescription.description: The SemanticField is a coarse-grained semantic category that can be attached to nouns, verbs or adjectives. Semantic field information is present e.g. in WordNet as lexicographer file names. Previously, this kind of semantic information has also been called supersenses or semantic types.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: The value or name of the semantic field. Examples of semantic field values are: location, artifact, event, communication, attribute

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.semantics.type.SemanticPredicate
typeDescription.description: One of the predicates of a sentence (often a main verb, but nouns and adjectives can also be predicates). The SemanticPredicate annotation can be attached to predicates in a sentences. Semantic predicates express events or situations and take semantic arguments expressing the participants in these events ore situations. All forms of main verbs can be annotated with a SemanticPredicate. However, there are also many nouns and adjectives that take arguments and can thus be annotated with a SemanticPredicate, e.g. event nouns, such as "suggestion" (with arguments what and by whom), or relational adjectives, such as "proud" (with arguments who and of what).

featureDescription.name: category
featureDescription.description: A more detailed specification of the predicate type depending on the theory being used, e.g. a frame name.

featureDescription.name: arguments
featureDescription.description: The predicate's arguments.

featureDescription.name: value
featureDescription.description: The sense identifier.

featureDescription.name: PennTree
featureDescription.description: Contains a Penn Treebank-style representation of a tree.

featureDescription.name: TransformationNames
featureDescription.description: The name(s) of the transformation(s) that have been performed on the PennTree

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.syntax.type.chunk.CONCJ
typeDescription.description: complex coordinating conjunctions such as "as well (as)" or "rather (than)"

featureDescription.name: parent
featureDescription.description: The parent constituent

typeDescription.name: de.tudarmstadt.ukp.dkpro.core.api.syntax.type.dependency.Dependency
typeDescription.description: A dependency relation between two tokens. The dependency annotation begin and end offsets correspond to those of the dependent.

featureDescription.name: Governor
featureDescription.description: The governor word

featureDescription.name: Dependent
featureDescription.description: The dependent word

featureDescription.name: DependencyType
featureDescription.description: The dependency type

featureDescription.name: flavor
featureDescription.description: Flavor of the dependency relation (basic, collapsed, enhanced, etc...)

typeDescription.name: de.uni_potsdam.acl.type.Chunk
typeDescription.description: Adding chunk information from opennlp trained on tiger NCs. Noun chunks only.

featureDescription.name: id
featureDescription.description: A text-level unique identitfier for corefering sets of mentions

typeDescription.name: de.uni_potsdam.acl.type.Quotation
typeDescription.description: A quotation is calculated as according to the bachelor thesis of Eric Kuhnt (2011)

featureDescription.name: speaker
featureDescription.description: a list of word positions. the word positions are relative to the sentence as are the head relations within the tokens

featureDescription.name: verb
featureDescription.description: the communication verb for the quotation. the word positions are relative to the sentence as are the head relations within the tokens

featureDescription.name: emptyValue
featureDescription.description: attribute to hold a value for "empty" timex3 tags

featureDescription.name: pos_SZ
featureDescription.description: POS from Salzburg MHDBDB

featureDescription.name: pos_UT
featureDescription.description: POS from Universal Dependency Tagset for German

featureDescription.name: Number
featureDescription.description: The line number

featureDescription.name: news
featureDescription.description: The probability the classifier assigned this article as of category 'news'

featureDescription.name: commentary
featureDescription.description: The probability the classifier assigned this article as of category 'commentary'

featureDescription.name: socal_sentiment
featureDescription.description: Sentence level sentiment as provided by the SO-CAL system (cf. Lexicon-based methods for sentiment analysis)

featureDescription.name: index
featureDescription.description: This value is the same as the index of this node in the top nodes list of terminals.

featureDescription.name: tokenIndex
featureDescription.description: The value of this corresponds to the nth token in the sentence that this terminal corresponds to. The value -1 means that this terminal does not correspond to a token (because it is a trace.) We assume that each token corresponds to a terminal.

value.description: ACE entity class - a particular, specific and unique real world entity.
ACE entity class - a kind or type of entity rather than a specific entity.
ACE entity class - a negatively quantified (uaually generic) entity
